author: roostercogburn
title: Great set, poor price point.
review:
Box/Instructions

For those of you who haven't read my other reviews, I generally don't have much to say about the boxes, the back showed the play features, the front set the scene, and it folded up very easily when I was recycling it.

The instructions didn't have any misprints, and it came with a comic I'm pretty sure, although it's been a little while since I flattened out and stored the instructions.

Parts

I'll address this right now: The number of parts for the cost is terrible.

However, the pieces that are included have some value to them. The large wheel/side rotor pieces are useful, similar to the Avenger's Quinjet, there are two different shaped cockpit pieces, and various grey, blue and red angled pieces that I haven't seen too many of. There are also something like 6 flick missiles if you require more as well, and a white net. I haven't seen a lot of the nets in this colour, and although a quick fact check will probably prove it is not unique to this set, it is unique to the sets in my collection.

Minifigures

Mary Jane Watson is included, in a black sleeveless shirt with a Spider-man themed heart on the front of it (the heck? That's pretty meta), is a long awaited inclusion, as she has been a long time character in the Spider-man universe. She has single colour pants, and the usual Marvel red hair (Pepper Potts, Jean Grey, etc), with the piece being the same as Peppers.

Carl Lucas aka Luke Cage aka Power Man has been a long awaited minifigure for me, as I have no context for Iron Fist (of Doc Ock's Lab fame) outside of being Power Man's partner. His headband is printed on his single sided head, and his outfit is a well printed yellow and black combination.

His inclusion, as I have found out between reviews of the Spider-man sets, is due to a Marvel cartoon version of our favorite web slinging super hero, Ultimate Spider-man. I'm still not familiar with this source material, but it looks like this is the reason for the seemingly random inclusion of Nova and Iron Fist (part of Spider-mans team along with Power Man and White Tiger) in previous sets over well known Spider-man partners such as the Human Torch or Black Cat. This also clarified my question as to why Spider-man all the sudden has a Batman sized arsenal of helicopters, motorcycles, planes, trains and automobiles.

Spider-man is also (obviously, from the title of the set) included. The same costume, same web piece, same everything, but he is still a very well done figure. I'm just bored that I have either 6 or 7 of him now.

The Green Goblin figure makes me feel how disconnected from the source material for these sets I really am. I remember him being only marginally larger, or even the same size, as Spider-man, but because there is finally a villain to stand up to the Hulk, I applaud his inclusion. The same format as the Troll/Goblin King/Hulk, but the torso/legs, head and I think even the arms have been slightly modified to make him look like he has armor on. He is an olive green, with a black and non reflective silver armor/clothing. He looks incredibly sinister, especially with the detail put into his focused eyes, gritting teeth and pointed ears and nose.

The build

The first section of the build is the Goblin's glider, which comic, movie or 90's cartoon purists will recognize. Dark grey, light grey with a little black and olive green are the colours, it has two flick missiles, boosters and some angled technic connectors to give the wings their bent looks. I am a little disappointed with the lack of pumpkin bombs, but I'll go out on a limb and say they aren't part of the Ultimate Spider-man mythology. It's a cool glider, and being part of the character, and the already low piece count, I'd say it had to be included. Once more, it is a great, iconic vehicle.

The build itself is pretty quick, and I'm willing to bet that many MOCs have been done just by looking at it.

The Spider-copter looks like something out of Avatar. It's different, I will say that. It has two separate cockpits, one for Power Man and one for Spider-man, the latter of which has a technic pin and attachment for Spider-man's web, so he can "jump" out of the copter and pursue the Green Goblin. The rest of the main body is made up of two "wings", which have two launchers, one for four flick missiles launched in pairs, the other for an unreliable web launcher, ending in large technic style "wheel" pieces with their own rotors. These "wheels" rotate too, for maneuverability I suppose. The top rotor and tail are the last completed parts of copter, and have smaller "fan" pieces on the tail, and larger rotor pieces for the main rotor.

Because of the number and size (that blue, long angled piece, the cockpit covers, the "wheel" rotors), it is a quick build. The two "launchers" are also slightly different, so follow the instructions so that you don't miss something, as I did simply mirroring the build for the web launcher from the missile launcher. There are some technic pins and pieces involved, but nothing revolutionary in the build process.

The completed model

As far as the Spider-man vehicles go, this one is my favorite. Part of it might be the colour, size and amount I spent on it, part of it is likely the discovery that TLG isn't just pumping out Spider-man themed vehicles to rob us (alright, me) of money for superfluous vehicles, as there is a source for them.

The top rotor occasionally needs maintenance, but both completed aircraft have a lot of play value, and are very swooshable. There are some great play features, such as the net launcher and the Spider-man's swing from inside the copter, that I haven't seen in such a small set.

You can display it or play with it with equal ease. It's a wonderful little set. However...

Overall opinion

...I bought this set for $55 dollars Canadian.

I understand there is a lot of overhead for a set like this. A new mold for the Green Goblin, the design of the minifigures (not to mention the paint on them), the design on of the set, the "character" price increase, the licensing costs...it all adds to the cost of a set. I get that, I'm sure many of you reading this get that.

However, both Hulk sets, as an example from a similarly licensed and priced set, got a lot more value for their respective sets in terms of product, without losing play value or value in the design of the set.

This mars my overall opinion of the set. That is really too bad, because it is well designed, would have a lot of play value, and even includes some rare-ish pieces. The cost per piece isn't usually a beef of mine, I look at the set as a whole, but this is just a glaring problem for me.

If the Green Goblin were included in a larger set, and the Spider-copter had another, smaller villain, this would have worked. Conversely, throwing another regular villain (or even generic security guard) from this series with a vehicle or small base of their own would have offset the cost.

If you're new to the Spider-man theme and looking for your first set, get the Daily Bugle set from last year. If you're already knee deep or higher, wait for a sale. Then again, I bought this set, full price, and it is a well designed and fun toy or model. Furthermore, I don't regret it, because this was my last Superhero set to buy from this wave, and I am, if nothing else, a completionist. I want more people to buy this set, and 7 year old me would freak out over getting a cool toy like this for my birthday, but my advice would be to wait for it to go on sale, as even 10 or 15 dollars off ($40 or $45 Canadian) would make it a lot easier to purchase.
